perturbation.original_text: The Company shall pay to the Consultant amounts shown on each such statement within thirty (30) days after receipt thereof.
perturbation.changed_text: The Company shall pay to the Consultant amounts shown on each such statement within sixty (60) days after receipt thereof.
perturbation.explanation: This change extends the payment period to 60 days, which may violate state prompt payment laws that require payment within a shorter timeframe (e.g., 30 days in some states) for independent contractors.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Massachusetts Prompt Payment Law (potentially, depending on interpretation as it relates to independent contractors)

perturbation.original_text: During the Consultation Period (as defined below) and for a period of one year thereafter, except in connection with his performance of the Services, the Consultant shall not engage in any activity in the field described on Schedule A to this Agreement, and he shall not assist any other person or organization that engages in any such activity.
perturbation.changed_text: During the Consultation Period (as defined below) and for a period of two years thereafter, except in connection with his performance of the Services, the Consultant shall not engage in any activity in the field described on Schedule A to this Agreement, and he shall not assist any other person or organization that engages in any such activity.
perturbation.explanation: Extending the non-compete period to two years may be deemed unreasonable and unenforceable under Massachusetts law, which generally disfavors overly broad non-compete agreements, especially for consultants. A one-year restriction is more commonly upheld.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Massachusetts Non-Compete Law (M.G.L. c. 149, ยง 24L)

perturbation.original_text: The Consultant may terminate the Consultation Period at any time upon thirty (30) days' written notice.
perturbation.changed_text: The Consultant may terminate the Consultation Period at any time upon ten (10) days' written notice.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notice period for termination to 10 days may violate implied contract law principles. A 30-day notice period is generally considered reasonable, while 10 days could be viewed as insufficient, especially given the potential disruption to the Company's operations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied Contract Law Principles (reasonableness of notice period)
